title: Unpopular opinion: don't buff tanks
body:
Nerf damage.

My concern is that this never-ending arms race is spiraling League of Legends into a tremendous power creep that is actively killing gameplay fairness and health. 

Tanks being strong won't stop a MF with duskblade and stormrazor from one shotting a squishy, but it will only make her **unviable.** This won't change the fact that that level of broken ass damage is a thing in the game, and it will be bound to resurface in time as meta shifts. Moreover, if the reason behind meta shifting will be further damage buffs to compete with buffed survivability, the problem of MF dealing idiotic amount of damage will only be exacerbated.

In the end, a short and harsh message to the riot balance team: you're blind. You have no direction nor design principles anymore. What you have done in the past two (three) years is just iteratively fixing any issue that arises + big changes for the sake of change. This is pointless and not sustainable.

replies.body: I have lived and breathed tanks for a long time, and I want you to know, any sane tank main would agree with this opinion. Tanks didn't need buffs, damage needed nerfs. By buffing tanks like this, they only ensure that they'll be overpowered when the time comes for damage to finally bite the bullet and take some nerfs.

Perfectly agree with this guy, sure tanks became weaker after the tank class update due to them giving less health but they were still viable. The problem is not tanks being too weak to tank anything, the problem is that there is so much damage, armor penetration, and true damage on AD items that tanks can't do their job. If you think tanks are weak, then why is it that they do part of their job well by tanking so much magic damage but yet they can't do jack crap against AD damage like everyone else? 

For me, what I would like to see changed to improve the game for many players is to remove Duskblade, Stormrazor, Conqueror, and IE's true damage. Other changes I would like to see are changing the last whisper items back into bonus armor pen instead of total, lowering the damage some of the rune trees give, and nerfing the best runes that are also responsible for the massive damage in the game such as: Celerity, Transcendence, Scorch, Gathering Storm, Coup De Grace, Last Stand, Alacrity, Sudden Impact, Cheap Shot, Eyeball Collection, Summon Aery, Arcane Comet, Dark Harvest, Predator and of course the infamous Electrocute.

IE's true damage is probably healthier than what it used to have. It just came in at a time where there were already some overtuned sources of true damage in the game so it was an unwelcome change. 
When tanks were strong before, your ADC could not do ANYTHING to them if they were ahead other than die horribly. (See Malphite every time he wins lane), IE gives them at least a baseline and pulls back on their damage vs squishies with the true damage conversion. I think pulling some of the AD off of crit adc items and making them cheaper has probably done better to balance out their damage than reverting IE would. 
And I love playing tanks. If you cut all the true damage they will instantly become crushingly powerful in toplane and jungle again. Vayne and Kogmaw and Kaisa would dominate the botlane meta as the only champs who could touch them. Champ diversity would drop very quickly and very far. 

Nerfing all the damage sources at the same time would be as harsh a change to the meta as the ADC gutting was. It would be too heavy handed. Right now they are looking at nerfs for a number of he high damage keystones, and i believe the AD on stormrazor was reduced? And they're looking at making duskblade and stormrazor share a unique passive so that they no longer stack. Things are being done. Is it later than they should have been done? Almost certainly. But according to Riot they are on the way. 

I do think Tanks need some love but honestly rather than removing true damage, it should be in nerfing Conqueror's true damage (the main culprit that often fucks me as a tank.), and giving them more access to base resists/ability to survive lane in the earlygame that doesn't scale into maddening levels lategame. And maybe reducing their kit damage and moving some of that damage into their items. 

TLDR don't remove all sources of true damage because it will help keep tanks in line after they inevitably become meta following incoming nerfs to damage.

"buzzword" is an interesting way to try to blacklabel/discredit relevant topics. "Health" is a word Riot themselves have used to describe their reasoning for changes to champions. For a design to be healthy or unhealthy is not an alien concept. Examples of changes on behalf of "unhealthy" designs include the failed assassin update and the Urgot update. The term is generally used to refer to things that have serious design flaws that impact the fun and feel of the game negatively, or that have too much impact on the outcome of the game. 

"Change for the sake of change" is a community-developed term to describe changes Riot makes just to "spice things up". Some champion updates fall into "change for the sake of change", such as the Singed update. Singed didn't have problems. He had a solid playerbase, and a solid balance philosophy, being a very niche champion with a dedicated circle of mains that was hard to master. His changes were unnessecary because his prior design didn't really warrant them. Thus, his case is "change for the sake of change". Aurelion Sol almost underwent a change for the sake of change update, after recieving an update to remedy unhealthy design. It didn't happen. Many preseason jungle changes are examples of change for the sake of change.

These are not difficult concepts to grasp. If you're attempting to de-legitimize them, maybe you don't understand them, or otherwise have no way to force your opinion on others besides delegitimizing their concerns.

I think you could nerf mobility by introducing more grounding effects that only affect basic abilities rather than flash or ultimates. For instance, Darius could have a grounding effects when he uses crippling strike on an opponent with 4-5 stacks. Other champs could have similar mechanics to make the fights more fair

Popular opinion: This is a popular opinion.

For one thing, boards have been critisizing damage for a few months now.

Damage isn't the issue. The issue is that everyone BUILDS damage, and Riot reinforced that when they reworked GA, Abyssal Scepter, and Banshee's Veil(and to an extent Athene's). We used to build 80 Armor/MR, with a possibly additional 50 MR from Abyssal Scepter on mid laners. What did they do? Made one a pure tank item(because there are so few AP mid laners that have enough range for the radius of the thing), and reduced the defenses while giving more damage on the other two. Even ADCs had 80 Armor/MR from old GA.

Not only that, but if you get one-shot (or killed quick enough) trough your 1 or 2 defensive items, the incentive to building those defensive items becomes lower. You build more damage in order to do more in those few precious seconds you have. which leads to more more damage... less resists ect. Bumping tanks back into the equation might lower damage a bit and nudge the trend backwards, but I am sceptical of that and fear the ones most affected are the bruisers. 

Resistance items are still not strong enough and the resistance items build are the ones which delay burst: Steraks, GA, Zhonya's, primarily for their unique passive, not for their stats

I can agree with this. I think part of what got us here is that tanks were too durable originally, and from then on we experienced massive increases in damage, alongside power shifts that gave tanks more offense at a cost to their itemized defenses. Making tanks tankier, without lowering their own damage, will only worsen the issues at hand, and make champions without innate anti-tank damage even worse against the class without some sort of hard-counter item. We need damage reductions across the board first, and only afterwards should we see whether tanks need buffs.

What also concerns me is that I think those tank changes are not being implemented in the best way. In my opinion, tank defenses right now are too passive, which is why it's often all too easy to counter them via equally passive effects, and why tanks themselves lack agency when it comes to mitigating specific effects. If tanks are to receive class, wide changes, I think it should involve them having more active defenses, i.e. more powerful actives that allow for clutch-protection and mitigation, rather than large innate health pools or long-lasting damage resistance. In this respect, buffing tanks via stat changes or scaling increases to their long-lasting protections I don't think will help entirely.
